text:
In any suitably configured Tomcat environment access an example as:

       /examples/jsp/snp/snoop.jsp

producing the nominal result.

Adding an extra slash to the path produces:

Error: 500
Location: /examples/jsp/snp//snoop.jsp
Internal Servlet Error:

org.apache.jasper.JasperException: Unable to compile class for 
JSP/usr/local/jakarta-tomcat/work/localhost_8080%
2Fexamples/_0002fjsp_0002fsnp_0002f_0002fsnoop_0002ejspsnoop_jsp_0.java:1: 
Identifier expected.
package jsp.snp.;
                ^
/usr/local/jakarta-tomcat/work/localhost_8080%
2Fexamples/_0002fjsp_0002fsnp_0002f_0002fsnoop_0002ejspsnoop_jsp_0.java:17: 
Superclass HttpJspBase of class 
_0002fjsp_0002fsnp_0002f_0002fsnoop_0002ejspsnoop_jsp_0 not found.
public class _0002fjsp_0002fsnp_0002f_0002fsnoop_0002ejspsnoop_jsp_0 extends 
HttpJspBase {
                                                                             ^
2 errors

	at org.apache.jasper.compiler.Compiler.compile(Compiler.java:254)
	at org.apache.jasper.servlet.JspServlet.doLoadJSP(JspServlet.java:462)


        etc. 


This is obviously not correct ... and caused me to go home in an unhappy state
yesterday. As a result I foolishly played around with my Windoze box's partition
tables and added yet another toaster to my collection.

You shall be hearing from my solicitors :-(

text:
There is a workaround - use "normal" URLs. Tomcat is very paranoid about 
that ( many security problems with "hacked" URLs ), and this requires a lot 
of attention. Very likely will be fixed in a future bug fix release 
( after 3.3 ).
